After the great drowning of Old Gods, his divine children were left disheartened. Each learned to cope with their sadness in their own way, and no different was our great goddess, Solaria, who found her salvation in redirecting her love to the mortal world. She watched them rise and fall with great interest. One man, among many, a noble lord of Zhaladusk, caught Solaria's watchful eye. She gazed with wonder and affection as the mortal known as Antero of Zhaladusk carved a thriving kingdom from a land once riddled with bandits and raiders.

It is believed that Solaria gained hope in Antero, thinking humanity was not as evil as depicted by those from the west. She desperately wanted to see what her father once saw in the creations he favored before being crushed by their betrayal. What lay in the heart of Solaria is only for her and Moonbeam to know for certain. Yet, she decided to come down to the mortal realm, taking the form of a human beauty, unbeknownst to Antero, who falsely thought her a foreign princess.

In their union, they bore a son, but Last Death, already suffering from the works of the western necromancers, and their attempted practice upon the demi-gods, was most displeased. She thought Solaria's actions were reckless and unbecoming of her nature. Last Death warned Solaria to take her child at birth.

In desperation, Solaria called upon the Goddess of fertility and love herself, Moonbeam, for advice and guidance. They devised a plan to sacrifice Solaria's mortal form to save her child. On her child's birth-day, the goddess ascended back to the celestial realm of the Ever-Light, forced to abandon her child and lover upon the mortal plane. Last Death, displeased by the Sun Goddess's actions, declared that in time she would take Solaria's lover and their child to the underworld, where Solaria's divine gaze does not shine, and so she would never see her mortal family again.

With saddened eyes, Solaria watched her family live their lives in her absence. She watched her son, now named Michael, grow into a man with great interest. He was touched by the gods, a man heavily blessed with the best features of his parents. Guided by his mother's unseen hand, he lived his life groomed to be the heir and future king of Zhaladusk.

When Michael's father passed into the underworld, Solaria couldn't bear to see him follow in his father's footsteps. Enter Xylix, the trickster god, who came to the Sun Goddess Solaria with hopes of a solution. He stated that if anyone would know how to trick the nature of death itself, it would be the wisest of their family, the God Lunaria of Darkness, Night, and Dreams.

Yet, when Lunaria was asked by his sister Solaria to help her child escape the clutches of the underworld, Lunaria initially refused, claiming that such an act was unwise. Solaria couldn't understand why her brother, the prince of the Ever-Dark, could not command his vassal-lord Last Death to do this favor. Lunaria preached the importance of maintaining the order and autonomy of the underworld. Xylix mocked Lunaria, claiming that he had underestimated Lunaria's wisdom and that he would not do this favor because he did not know how. Lunaria knew this was false and remained unbothered.

Xylix sought the counsel of Moonbeam and suggested that it was not a lack of knowledge that prevented Lunaria from helping his sister, but a lack of love. Under the pressure of Xylix, Moonbeam, and his twin sister Solaria, Lunaria agreed to help despite his better judgment. He went to the underworld to Last Death to ask for her blessing, which she denied, calling Lunaria a fool for submitting to their plot. However, unable to refuse Lunaria, she allowed him to scoop a vial of water from the river of the underworld. Lunaria gave this vial to his sister Solaria, who then gave it to her son so that he may become immortal.

Yet, Xylix's laughter still echoes today, as this potion transformed Solaria's beloved son into an unrecognizable creature set ablaze by his mother's light. He gained immortality, but at the cost of the lives of the mortals he once ruled. Solaria was filled with shame, knowing that her actions corrupted her son and his kingdom forevermore, forced to not even look upon him and his entire bloodline of vampiric parasites unless they perish in the sunlight.

So, in pity and in love for his twin sister, Lunaria adopted Michael and his future spawn to be loved as his own, as Solaria once loved him. And this is how the first of the nite-kin, also known as vampires, came to be. The wounds between Solaria and Lunaria from these days have yet to be mended.
